title: Atomic Scale Observation of Incommensurate Modulation in Ba2TiSi2O8
content: Fresnoite (Ba2TiSi2O8), displays high electrical resistivity and strong piezoelectric response at elevated temperatures, making it a promising material for sensor applications. At approximately 160 °C, fresnoite undergoes a transition from a commensurate tetragonal structure to an incommensurate structure, significantly impacting its physical properties, including piezoelectric and pyroelectric coefficients [1]. Recent findings have revealed that the incommensurate structural modulation induces phasons—a type of quasiparticle excitation—that not only enhances fresnoite’s thermal conductivity but also facilitates the transmission of thermal energy at a velocity approximately four times faster than the speed of sound in this material [2–3]. This remarkable discovery emphasizes the necessity for a detailed analysis to clarify the incommensurate structure of fresnoite further.
